page.title: 12ECOLOGY
page.content: The study area is underlain by rocks of the Triassic age except for a small part to the east of Gleaston and north of Newbiggin which has older Carboniferous rocks.The Triassic rocks are mostly sandstone and the Carboniferous are limestone.No solid rock can be seen in the area because of the thick deposits of glacial drift brought down during the Ice Age.The rocks underlying the area have been investigated by the Institute of Geological Sciences with a borehole near Gleaston.The beach contains pebbles of limestone and sandstone washed out of the glacial drift along the coast by the sea.Also on the beach are pebbles that do not belong to the area but have been brought in by sea currents and tides.
